data.title: Dec 00 - In an arcade of the tomb of Il-khan Oljeitu (Ilkhanate, 1306-1317) Soltaniyeh, Zanjan prov., Iran
data.meta_description: This 14th cent. Ilkhanate tomb (Ilkhanate = Mongol-era and of the Il-khanate, a portion or division of the vast Mongol empire in the early 14th cent. which includes Iran) is the greatest surviving Ilkhanate building, and is capped by the largest dome (49 m.s in height) built by 1312 (the date of its completion) in the Islamic world. Built in only 10 years (1302-12) here in Oljeitu's new capital (replacing Tabriz), it's claimed to have been an inspiration for Brunelleschi in his design of the later and much taller dome (114 m.s in height) of the Duomo in Florence, and to have anticipated the Taj Mahal. www.flickr.com/photos/27784269@N06/3072389722/ www.flickr.com/photos/rocor/465840311/ Is the dome here at Soltaniyeh the world's oldest double dome? I haven't confirmed this with research online, but it was the first in Iran (according to UNESCO) which became famous for its double domes. It was also the world's 2nd tallest dome (49 m.s from the base of the bldg.) after that of the then 800 yr.- old Hagia Sofia (@ 55 m.s) when completed in 1312, decades before work on the dome of the Duomo had begun in Florence, and its completion at that time would involve quite a coincidence if it wasn't an inspiration for Brunelleschi. (A recent National Geographic article re the Duomo presents a pictorial procession of historical domes, www.nationalgeographic.org/hires/domed-buildings/ which begins with Rome's Pantheon [righfully so, a much earlier dome but on a round base] and Hagia Sofia, with the Duomo 3rd, ignoring Soltaniyeh). It's less controversial to state that the dome here anticipated the Taj Mahal. - Western academics tend to ignore the role played by Persian architects in the revival of the dome in the European renaissance. Here in this lecture on Palladio, this prof. states the following at the 3:47 min. pt.: "Realize that when Brunelleschi built his dome in Florence, that's the first free-standing dome that's been built since the Pantheon was built." www.youtube.com/watch?v=G6waOKCO-0s (I'm all for the big picture. I wrote the following in a comment to his video.: "The early 14th cent. Ilkhanate dome at the tomb of the Mongol khan Oljeitu at Soltaniyeh in what is today western Iran, a pioneering double dome, is said to have influenced Brunelleschi. ... The first high dome built on a square base dates from the 3rd cent. and still stands today in the palace of Ardeshir Papakan near Firuzabad. And arguably the greatest dome ever built, that of Hagia Sofia, post-dates the Pantheon, and plenty of domes sprang up in Byzantium in the so-called dark ages to follow, many centuries before Palladio and Brunelleschi. (But props to Brunelleschi for the height of his dome, surpassing Hagia Sophia, and by far, for the first time.)" - The famous Selimiye mosque of Edirne, Turkey (1566-'74), the great Turkish architect Mimar Sinan's masterpiece, is considered to be the culmination of Ottoman architecture. "The octagonal shape of that dome's support was most likely the result of the influence of the tomb of Öljeitü in Soltaniyeh, which Sinan had visited during the Baghdad campaign of Sultan Suleyman." turkisharchaeonews.net/object/selimiye-mosque-edirne - I don't have a photo of the famous dome as it was covered in scaffolding outside and obscured by it inside when I was there. :( It was the same sad state of affairs inside the Hagia Sofia when I was in Istanbul earlier that year. - "10,000 men laid the foundations of the tomb and surrounding structures, incl. 500 carpenters and 5,000 marble-masons. Architectural engineers were first sent to survey and measure the vast palace audience hall of the [already ancient] palace of the Sassanian shahs at Ctesiphon, Iraq." Oljeitu's stated intention "was not to build a [mausoleum] for himself, but to bring the remains of Husein, the 3rd Imam [Mohamed's martyred grandson], from Kerbela to Soltaniyeh. Oljeitu had been slow to accept Islam, preferring first Buddhism and then Christianity, the faith of his mother, before adopting Shiite Islam, and then converting to Sunni Islam in 1313. It was at that point that he announced that the brick mausoleum would be his own." (Shiites believe that Mohamed's divine inspiration was inherited by a succession of 12 Imams, Sunnis don't, and so Hussein is much more important to Shiites than Sunnis). Coincidentally, Oljeitu had converted on the heels of the completion of construction on the mausoleum. Had he pulled a fast one? Now he'd be buried in one of the world's greatest tombs. - More of it: www.flickr.com/photos/simon_p_white/2175934386/ www.flickr.com/photos/haug/1013915645/ www.flickr.com/photos/27784269@N06/3072389768/
